content:
re : It gave me a warning that the newer version changed my profiles and it's not compatible so I downloaded the new version again.

Ever since version 68* a dedicated profile is used for each program installation of Thunderbird.

  • https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/dedicated-profile-thunderbird-installation

Try this:

  • Exit Thunderbird now.
  • In bottom windows search type: %Appdata% - see image below as guide
  • Select the '%Appdata%' file folder
  • Click on 'Roaming' folder to see contents'
  • Click on 'Thunderbird' folder to see contents
  • Click on the 'Profiles' folder to see contents
  • You will see some profile name folders and one will be the original containing your data.
  • click on the 'profile name' folder to see contents - profile name folder typically looks like this: 123dfg4.default or similar.

If the 'Mail' or 'Imap Mail' fodler has your mail accounts then you know which profile name is correct. Make a note of the 'profile name' folder.

  • In the correct 'profile name' folder locate the 'compatibility.ini' file - move it to the desktop as a temp backup - so you can replace if required.

Start Thunderbird.

  • Help > Troubleshooting Information
  • Under 'Application Basics' near the bottom locate 'Profiles' and click on 'about:profiles'

It opens in a new tab. It will list all your profiles.

  • look for the one which says 'Root directory: and it points to the correct profile name folder.

Below it you will see some buttons.

  • Click on 'Set as default profile'
  • Click on 'Launch Profile'

It should open in a new window. Does it show all your emails?

If yes: close the original Thunderbird window.

Please report on results.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
For many imap accounts if email was put into the default imap TRash folder, the server empties the Trash periodically by default. This may not be the same for the server you are using.

Right click on imap Trash folder and select 'compact' Also do the same for he Inbox folder.
creator: Toad-Hall

content: Thank you, compacting Trash and Inbox solved the problem.

content: just download from Thunderbird.net and reinstall. That has been a sure fire fix for those platform issues for the last 10 years.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
What are your settings? They recommend:

incoming POP: pop3.mail.dk, 995, SSL/TLS, normal password, User Name = email address

incoming IMAP: imap.mail.dk, 993, SSL/TLS, normal password, User Name = email address

outgoing SMTP: asmtp.mail.dk, 587, STARTTLS, normal password, User Name = email address

If you have those and it doesn't work, state your antivirus (if it's not Windows/MS Security) and VPN if applicable.

content:
OK - thanks for images.

It looks like you have 'View' > 'Folders' > 'Unified' selected.

That means the top 'Inbox' is a 'Unified Inbox' and it should contain all emails which are located in all Inboxes for all accounts. As you have two mail account - BT and Local Folders, that means both would be under 'Unified Inbox'

As you only have one BT account then you do not really need to use 'Unified' option. Please tell me if you really want to use 'Unified' folders.

So do this first and then we can see which folders are really in the wrong location. 'View' > 'Folders' and select 'All' Then 'View' > 'Folders' > and select the 'Unified' to uncheck that option.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
It is possible to have multiple profiles, with each one having a set of accounts, e.g. gmail accounts, work accounts etc. The Profile Switcher add-on simplifies the management.

If you wanted to aggregate accounts to, e.g. show all gmail Inboxes in a common folder, a Saved Search is available from File/New. Unified Folders is a special case of saved search.

One simple way to apply some organization is to order the accounts in the Folder Pane by rearranging them by drag and drop in Account Settings. Less important accounts can be collapsed to a single line in the Folder Pane.
creator: sfhowes

content:
I think that I figured out a way to the have the accounts organized as I wanted.

Create a folder structure as shown above for Gmail, GMX & Yahoo under the Local Folder (and move the Local Folder to the top).

Then create saved searches for each account's inbox, containing all E-mail messages and place under the appropriate folder (Gmail, GMX & Yahoo).

I can also create another saved search for sent messages etc.

I wish though that there was a way to organize the original accounts directly as shown in my image.

content:
If you are refusing to work with folk here, then there is exactly nothing to be achieved interacting further as this is a peer user support forum. It is not working and the software is installed on your computer. So the only way it might come to work is if you change something.

You are most assuredly not interacting with your chosen "meat head" or "goof ball" you are tossing out rather nasty comments in a forum of your fellow users. There is a feedback link on the help menu of Thunderbird if you wish to offer the developer team feedback, but they have themselves pretty well insulated. Language such as you have used here will simply get your account suspended. It probably should here as well, but honestly I am pretty slack at imposing the Mozilla guidelines for use of this site.

BTW Thunderbird is not a Mozilla product, despite many folk thinking it is and them hosting this support web site. You will note it is not listed on their products page https://www.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/products/

Further information about who makes Thunderbird can be found here https://www.thunderbird.net/en-US/about/
creator: MattAuSupport
